46.text:
The real version of the Liebherr LTM1400 was
built in the 1990s and it had a maximum lifting

52.text:
capacity of 400 tonnes. This model of it by
YCC is delivered in a robust outer shipping

58.text:
container and that provides proper protection
to the model box inside. The box itself is

64.text:
Liebherr branded and it has line drawings
of the real crane on the outside. Pulling

69.text:
out the insides the model is contained within
a pair of expanded polystyrene trays and the

73.text:
first thing to look at is the manual. A cautionary
note directs you to read about handling the

78.text:
model without damaging it, and the first part
of the manual is a reprint of original Liebherr

83.text:
information. The rest of the manual is about
the model and it is really good. One really

87.text:
nice touch on the packaging is the two trays
are clipped together and that is so much better

91.text:
than having to cut tape. With the lid separated
we can take a look inside the box and many

96.text:
of the parts are wrapped in soft paper. Also
included is a nice little commemorative keyring.

102.text:
Also in the box are many bags of small parts
and most of them are properly labelled so

107.text:
you can tie them up to the instructions in
the manual. There was only one small defect

112.text:
on the review model and that is a loose engine
cover, but YCC's customer service is very

117.text:
good and they sent the part needed to make
the fix. You can see what a small part it

121.text:
is and that just shows you the kind of model
engineering involved in this model. Using

126.text:
our old friend super glue, and fat fingers
and thumbs, a good repair could be made.

139.text:
To start the assembly we will put the crane
in transport mode and we will begin by assembling

143.text:
and connecting up the superlift. The first
thing you can notice is that the connections

147.text:
are made with very small pins, and many of
them are of different sizes. So for sure you

153.text:
definitely don't want to be dropping the pins
on the floor, and if you are handling the

157.text:
model, you need to make sure the pins are
not working free. A spool of thread is provided

161.text:
and the manual tells you what lengths you
need for the various winches, so for the superlift

166.text:
the length of thread has been cut, and we
start by fixing one end at the tying-off point.

172.text:
You feed it through the hole, tie a knot and
then tidy up the loose end. After that the

177.text:
thread is taken through the superlift arrangement
and then tied off and wound up on the winch.

183.text:
At the back of the crane carrier there are
an interesting couple of options. One is to

187.text:
attach a spare wheel holder, or if you don't
anticipate getting a puncture in the display

192.text:
case, you can add a tool box instead. There
is also a choice of options for the windscreen

197.text:
in the crane cab. There is an open version
for when the crane is operating, but we will

202.text:
fit the closed one here and use a little bit
of plastic putty to keep the windscreen in

206.text:
place, and if you do that it is a bit like
glazing a real window, but with giant mega-huge

212.text:
hands. Moving on and the real crane had its
own system for storing the outrigger pads

218.text:
during transport. On each side of the crane
there is a little loader arm, and the pads

223.text:
can be positioned on it and folded back into
a transport position. Another tiny detail

229.text:
on the crane is that there are separate wheel
chocks and they get positioned in their own

232.text:
holder. Moving on we have cut another length
of thread and are now tying it on to the main

237.text:
winch drum, and the good thing is that the
winch drum has a positive brake action. For

242.text:
this assembly we will add on the smallest
of the three hooks that come with the crane,

245.text:
but to do that it is easier to raise the boom
a little, so we need to install the locking

250.text:
screws into the main cylinder rams. Once they
are in we can easily raise the boom and then

255.text:
lock it in to a pose using the tool that is
provided. Reeving the hook is a little bit

260.text:
tricky because of its high precision and retaining
bars, but there is a proper tying-off cleat

265.text:
that gets pinned to the top of the boom. There
is also a hoist cut-off chain which has got

269.text:
an incredibly small connection at the top
of the boom. In fact this small connection

274.text:
is a great indicator of the precision of this
model. Once the chain is attached the bottom

278.text:
is clipped onto the hoist rope. With the boom
up we will add tool box cover to the crane

283.text:
carrier, and then we'll move round to the
front where there is an attachment point for

287.text:
the hook. As you see those pins are very small
and you don't want to lose them. With the

292.text:
pin in place there is then a tiny length of
chain which you can use to secure the hook.

297.text:
In this section there is one more thing to
add which is again illustrates the attention

300.text:
to detail on this model, and it is a small
magnetic cover for the screw on the ram, and

306.text:
you can see how magnetic it is because it
has flown off to the side and attached itself

309.text:
to an outrigger pad, but if we persuade it
to come loose, we can then stick it on the

314.text:
locking screw for the ram. With that done
the model is all set up in transport configuration,

320.text:
and with some other models we can set up a
transport diorama.

348.text:
Looking underneath the detail is very good
in terms of the steering and suspension components,

353.text:
and it is all modelled in metal. The wheels
are very good with Michelin and tyre details

357.text:
in the tyre side walls. The carrier cab is
finely detailed including internally, and

363.text:
that continues on behind the cab with fans
visible below the grille, and a really nice

367.text:
exhaust system. The outriggers are all metal
with sharp graphics, and there is really fine

372.text:
detailing on the outrigger pads. The view
inside the crane cab is also excellent with

377.text:
all of the instruments modelled. There are
plenty of hydraulic hoses and some very nice

381.text:
walkways and mesh grilles on the body. Another
very nice aspect is the really sharp detailing

387.text:
on the counterweight. The main boom rams are
metal and there is nice detailing on the boom

393.text:
itself. There is fine detail at the collars
including working rollers and boom locks,

398.text:
and there is also good detailing at the boom
head with free-rolling metal pulleys. The

403.text:
superlift arrangement is also good with all
of the brackets on the structure having usable

407.text:
holes. There are three different hook blocks
supplied with the model and they are very

412.text:
high quality, the hooks rotate and they also
have spring-loaded safety catches. Inside

418.text:
the blocks there are retaining bars and metal
pulleys.

430.text:
We will start with the crane in upside down
mode. There is linked steering on some of

435.text:
the axles, and there is a realistically implemented
suspension on all of the axles. At the front

441.text:
of the crane all four axles are linked together,
and it is a model engineering challenge to

445.text:
get all four axles to steer, and steer proportionately.
Moving out on to the test track and the crane

452.text:
rolls along well in a straight line. All of
the tyres are properly grounded and each of

456.text:
the axles holds its position. Let's now give
it a test of the steering and the four front

461.text:
axles are linked together, as are the two
rear axles, and with that the crane is able

466.text:
to follow a shallow curve. There are some
very small working features on the carrier

471.text:
and that includes fold-down access ladders,
and the cover on the control console for the

476.text:
outriggers also opens. With the access ladders
down, we can begin to set up the crane, and

482.text:
we'll start by unloading the outrigger pads.
With the pads laid out we can then pull out

487.text:
the two-stage outrigger beams. and these can
be set at either 50% or 100% extension. The

494.text:
pistons just unscrew to reveal a smooth piston
surface, and another very nice touch on the

499.text:
model is that the pads are magnetic so they
will stick on to the pistons while you put

503.text:
in the spreader plates underneath. Another
very tiny detail is that locking pins are

508.text:
provided to be able to lock the extension
of the outrigger beams. The whole outrigger

513.text:
arrangement is strong on the model because
it will support the crane wheels-free. Next

519.text:
we can fire-up the crane and start by swinging
the cab into its operating position. Next

525.text:
we will take off the cover cap for the ram
screws, and then we can smoothly raise the

530.text:
boom into an operating position. Once it is
there it is locked into place with the screws.

536.text:
The counterweight attaches to a secondary
winch assembly and to make that look a bit

540.text:
more realistic, we can add the thread that
is left over on the spool and to do that we

544.text:
will tie the end on to the winch drum and
then wind all the thread on using some nifty

549.text:
wrist action, and that leaves us with the
winch drum looking more realistic. The winch

554.text:
assembly sits on top of the main counterweight
plates, and it is secured in position using

559.text:
some more of the very tiny pins. Once it is
fixed the real crane would turn around and

564.text:
pick up its counterweight but in the model
world you need to manually fit the counterweight

569.text:
on. To secure it there is another piece of
micro-model engineering combined with yet

574.text:
another small pin. Again this is all very
high quality model engineering and it also

580.text:
includes connecting up some hydraulic lines
to the main crane body. With the counterweight

585.text:
attached you can then load up with more blocks
if you want. Another great detail to improve

593.text:
the look of the model is this piece which
goes in to the secondary winch assembly. For

598.text:
the next part we have detached the superlift
assembly and we can telescope the boom. A

602.text:
great feature of the model is that it replicates
the locking pins that the real crane used

606.text:
to have, and they are spring-loaded and you
pull them out so you can raise the telescopic

610.text:
boom section. The model also accurately replicates
the real machine because it has boom locking

616.text:
holes at the 50% 92% and 100% extension positions.
And here the crane is set up with all sections

624.text:
at the 50% boom lock. To open up the superlift
you use a special key in the superlift winch,

638.text:
and you carefully unwind it as you raise up
the superlift. Using the superlift tensions

643.text:
up the boom allowing heavier loads to be lifted,
and here is the crane at full extension with

655.text:
So how big is
the model at maximum height? Well with the

658.text:
tape out it is about 42 inches or 107 centimetres.
There are plenty of other features on the

663.text:
model including opening driving cab doors,
and the two covers for the engine in the carrier

669.text:
also open, and that lets you see a really
nicely detailed metal engine. The crane cab

675.text:
also features a nice tilting mechanism, and
it has also got a sliding door which works

680.text:
quite well too. But there is more because
there is opening engine covers on the crane

685.text:
and the silver heads that you can see are
magnets which are used to keep the covers

689.text:
shut in a closed position. Even the optional
toolbox at the rear has got opening doors.

699.text:
In summary YCC has produced a very high quality
precision model. Of course it is not cheap,

705.text:
but it does include excellent detailing and
excellent functionality as well, and at the

710.text:
time of the review this is the best mass-produced
crane model seen by Cranes Etc. If you are

715.text:
looking for the best the this model is certainly
outstanding.
